trans-unit.source: Provision a Spark cluster on HDInsight and use Spark SQL from Zeppelin and Jupyter for interactive analysis | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Provision a Spark cluster on HDInsight and use Spark SQL from Zeppelin and Jupyter for interactive analysis | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Step-by-step instructions on how to quickly provision an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight and then use Spark SQL from Zeppelin and Jupyter notebooks to run interactive queries.
trans-unit.target: Step-by-step instructions on how to quickly provision an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight and then use Spark SQL from Zeppelin and Jupyter notebooks to run interactive queries.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provision Apache Spark on HDInsight and run interactive queries using Spark SQL</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provision Apache Spark on HDInsight and run interactive queries using Spark SQL</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Learn how to provision an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight using the Quick Create option and then use the web-based <linkText>Zeppelin</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Jupyter</linkText><title></title> notebooks to run Spark SQL interactive queries on the Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to provision an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight using the Quick Create option and then use the web-based <linkText>Zeppelin</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Jupyter</linkText><title></title> notebooks to run Spark SQL interactive queries on the Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: ![Get started using Apache Spark in HDInsight](./media/hdinsight-apache-spark-zeppelin-notebook-jupyter-spark-sql/HDI.GetStartedFlow.Spark.png "Get started using Apache Spark in HDInsight tutorial.
trans-unit.target: ![Get started using Apache Spark in HDInsight](./media/hdinsight-apache-spark-zeppelin-notebook-jupyter-spark-sql/HDI.GetStartedFlow.Spark.png "Get started using Apache Spark in HDInsight tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Steps illustrated: create a storage account; provision a cluster; run Spark SQL statements")
trans-unit.target: Steps illustrated: create a storage account; provision a cluster; run Spark SQL statements")

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have an Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have an Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you provision an HDInsight version 3.2 cluster, which is based on Spark version 1.3.1.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you provision an HDInsight version 3.2 cluster, which is based on Spark version 1.3.1.

trans-unit.source: For information about HDInsight versions and their SLAs, see <linkText>HDInsight component versioning</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about HDInsight versions and their SLAs, see <linkText>HDInsight component versioning</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article create an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight by using basic configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article create an Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight by using basic configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: For information about other cluster configuration settings (such as using additional storage, Azure virtual network, or a metastore for Hive), see <linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters using custom options</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about other cluster configuration settings (such as using additional storage, Azure virtual network, or a metastore for Hive), see <linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters using custom options</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To provision a Spark cluster
trans-unit.target: To provision a Spark cluster

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click NEW, Click Data Analytics, and then click HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Click NEW, Click Data Analytics, and then click HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating a new cluster in the Azure Preview Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating a new cluster in the Azure Preview Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter a Cluster Name, select Hadoop for the Cluster Type, and from the Cluster Operating System drop-down, select Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter.
trans-unit.target: Enter a Cluster Name, select Hadoop for the Cluster Type, and from the Cluster Operating System drop-down, select Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear beside the cluster name if it is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear beside the cluster name if it is available.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enter cluster name and type</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enter cluster name and type</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, click the Subscription entry to select the Azure subscription that will be used for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, click the Subscription entry to select the Azure subscription that will be used for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Click Resource Group to see a list of existing resource groups and then select the one to create the cluster in.
trans-unit.target: Click Resource Group to see a list of existing resource groups and then select the one to create the cluster in.

trans-unit.source: Or, you can click Create New and then enter the name of the new resource group.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can click Create New and then enter the name of the new resource group.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear to indicate if the new group name is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear to indicate if the new group name is available.

trans-unit.source: This entry will default to one of your existing resource groups, if any are available.
trans-unit.target: This entry will default to one of your existing resource groups, if any are available.

trans-unit.source: Click Credentials, then enter a Cluster Login Username and Cluster Login Password.
trans-unit.target: Click Credentials, then enter a Cluster Login Username and Cluster Login Password.

trans-unit.source: If you want to enable remote desktop on the cluster node, for Enable Remote Desktop, click Yes, and then specify the required values.
trans-unit.target: If you want to enable remote desktop on the cluster node, for Enable Remote Desktop, click Yes, and then specify the required values.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial does not require remote desktop so you can skip this.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial does not require remote desktop so you can skip this.

trans-unit.source: Click Select at the bottom to save the credentials configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select at the bottom to save the credentials configuration.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provide cluster credentials</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provide cluster credentials</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Data Source to choose an existing data source for the cluster, or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Click Data Source to choose an existing data source for the cluster, or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: When you provision a Hadoop cluster in HDInsight, you specify an Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a Hadoop cluster in HDInsight, you specify an Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: A specific Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system, like in the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS).
trans-unit.target: A specific Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system, like in the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS).

trans-unit.source: By default, the HDInsight cluster is provisioned in the same data center as the storage account you specify.
trans-unit.target: By default, the HDInsight cluster is provisioned in the same data center as the storage account you specify.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data source blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data source blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Currently you can select an Azure Storage Account as the data source for an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Currently you can select an Azure Storage Account as the data source for an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Use the following to understand the entries on the Data Source blade.
trans-unit.target: Use the following to understand the entries on the Data Source blade.

trans-unit.source: Selection Method: Set this to From all subscriptions to enable browsing of storage accounts from all your subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Selection Method: Set this to From all subscriptions to enable browsing of storage accounts from all your subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Set this to Access Key if you want to enter the Storage Name and Access Key of an existing storage account.
trans-unit.target: Set this to Access Key if you want to enter the Storage Name and Access Key of an existing storage account.

trans-unit.source: Select storage account / Create New: Click Select storage account to browse and select an existing storage account you want to associate with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Select storage account / Create New: Click Select storage account to browse and select an existing storage account you want to associate with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Or, click Create New to create a new storage account.
trans-unit.target: Or, click Create New to create a new storage account.

trans-unit.source: Use the field that appears to enter the name of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Use the field that appears to enter the name of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: Choose Default Container: Use this to enter the name of the default container to use for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Choose Default Container: Use this to enter the name of the default container to use for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: While you can enter any name here, we recommend using the same name as the cluster so that you can easily recognize that the container is used for this specific cluster.
trans-unit.target: While you can enter any name here, we recommend using the same name as the cluster so that you can easily recognize that the container is used for this specific cluster.

trans-unit.source: Location: The geographic region that the storage account is in, or will be created in.
trans-unit.target: Location: The geographic region that the storage account is in, or will be created in.

trans-unit.source: Selecting the location for the default data source will also set the location of the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Selecting the location for the default data source will also set the location of the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The cluster and default data source must be located in the same region.
trans-unit.target: The cluster and default data source must be located in the same region.

trans-unit.source: Click Select to save the data source configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select to save the data source configuration.

trans-unit.source: Click Node Pricing Tiers to display information about the nodes that will be created for this cluster.
trans-unit.target: Click Node Pricing Tiers to display information about the nodes that will be created for this cluster.

trans-unit.source: Set the number of worker nodes that you need for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Set the number of worker nodes that you need for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The estimated cost of the cluster will be shown within the blade.
trans-unit.target: The estimated cost of the cluster will be shown within the blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Node pricing tiers blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Node pricing tiers blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Select to save the node pricing configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select to save the node pricing configuration.

trans-unit.source: On the New HDInsight Cluster blade, ensure that Pin to Startboard is selected, and then click Create.
trans-unit.target: On the New HDInsight Cluster blade, ensure that Pin to Startboard is selected, and then click Create.

trans-unit.source: This will create the cluster and add a tile for it to the Startboard of your Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will create the cluster and add a tile for it to the Startboard of your Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: The icon will indicate that the cluster is provisioning, and will change to display the HDInsight icon once provisioning has completed.
trans-unit.target: The icon will indicate that the cluster is provisioning, and will change to display the HDInsight icon once provisioning has completed.

trans-unit.source: | While provisioning | Provisioning complete | | ------------------ | --------------------- | | <linkText>Provisioning indicator on startboard</linkText> | <linkText>Provisioned cluster tile</linkText> |
trans-unit.target: | While provisioning | Provisioning complete | | ------------------ | --------------------- | | <linkText>Provisioning indicator on startboard</linkText> | <linkText>Provisioned cluster tile</linkText> |

trans-unit.source: It will take some time for the cluster to be created, usually around 15 minutes.
trans-unit.target: It will take some time for the cluster to be created, usually around 15 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Use the tile on the Startboard, or the Notifications entry on the left of the page to check on the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: Use the tile on the Startboard, or the Notifications entry on the left of the page to check on the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: Once the provisioning completes, click the tile for the Spark cluster from the Startboard to launch the cluster blade.
trans-unit.target: Once the provisioning completes, click the tile for the Spark cluster from the Startboard to launch the cluster blade.

trans-unit.source: After you have provisioned a cluster, you can use a web-based Zeppelin notebook to run Spark SQL interactive queries against the Spark HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: After you have provisioned a cluster, you can use a web-based Zeppelin notebook to run Spark SQL interactive queries against the Spark HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will use a sample data file (hvac.csv) available by default on the cluster to run some interactive Spark SQL queries.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will use a sample data file (hvac.csv) available by default on the cluster to run some interactive Spark SQL queries.

trans-unit.source: The notebook you create following the instructions below is also available by default on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The notebook you create following the instructions below is also available by default on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After you have launched Zeppelin, you will find this notebook by the name Zeppelin HVAC tutorial.
trans-unit.target: After you have launched Zeppelin, you will find this notebook by the name Zeppelin HVAC tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Launch the Zeppelin notebook.
trans-unit.target: Launch the Zeppelin notebook.

trans-unit.source: From the Spark cluster blade, click Quick Links, and then from the Cluster Dashboard blade, click Zeppelin Notebook.
trans-unit.target: From the Spark cluster blade, click Quick Links, and then from the Cluster Dashboard blade, click Zeppelin Notebook.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions on the page that opens up to launch the notebook.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions on the page that opens up to launch the notebook.

trans-unit.source: Create a new notebook.
trans-unit.target: Create a new notebook.

trans-unit.source: From the header pane, click Notebook, and then click Create New Note.
trans-unit.target: From the header pane, click Notebook, and then click Create New Note.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Zeppelin notebook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Zeppelin notebook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the same page, under the Notebook heading, you should see a new notebook with the name starting with Note XXXXXXXXX.
trans-unit.target: On the same page, under the Notebook heading, you should see a new notebook with the name starting with Note XXXXXXXXX.

trans-unit.source: Click the new notebook.
trans-unit.target: Click the new notebook.

trans-unit.source: On the web page for the new notebook, click the heading, and change the name of the notebook if you want to.
trans-unit.target: On the web page for the new notebook, click the heading, and change the name of the notebook if you want to.

trans-unit.source: Press ENTER to save the name change.
trans-unit.target: Press ENTER to save the name change.

trans-unit.source: Also, make sure the notebook header shows a Connected status in the top-right corner.
trans-unit.target: Also, make sure the notebook header shows a Connected status in the top-right corner.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Zeppelin notebook status</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Zeppelin notebook status</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Load sample data into a temporary table.
trans-unit.target: Load sample data into a temporary table.

trans-unit.source: When you provision a Spark cluster in HDInsight, the sample data file, hvac.csv, is copied to the associated storage account under \HdiSamples\SensorSampleData\hvac.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a Spark cluster in HDInsight, the sample data file, hvac.csv, is copied to the associated storage account under \HdiSamples\SensorSampleData\hvac.

trans-unit.source: In the empty paragraph that is created by default in the new notebook, paste the following snippet.
trans-unit.target: In the empty paragraph that is created by default in the new notebook, paste the following snippet.

trans-unit.source: Press SHIFT + ENTER or click the Play button for the paragraph to run the snippet.
trans-unit.target: Press SHIFT + ENTER or click the Play button for the paragraph to run the snippet.

trans-unit.source: The status on the right-corner of the paragraph should progress from READY, PENDING, RUNNING to FINISHED.
trans-unit.target: The status on the right-corner of the paragraph should progress from READY, PENDING, RUNNING to FINISHED.

trans-unit.source: The output shows up at the bottom of the same paragraph.
trans-unit.target: The output shows up at the bottom of the same paragraph.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot looks like the following:
trans-unit.target: The screenshot looks like the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a temporary table from raw data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a temporary table from raw data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can also provide a title to each paragraph.
trans-unit.target: You can also provide a title to each paragraph.

trans-unit.source: From the right-hand corner, click the Settings icon, and then click Show title.
trans-unit.target: From the right-hand corner, click the Settings icon, and then click Show title.

trans-unit.source: You can now run Spark SQL statements on the hvac table.
trans-unit.target: You can now run Spark SQL statements on the hvac table.

trans-unit.source: Paste the following query in a new paragraph.
trans-unit.target: Paste the following query in a new paragraph.

trans-unit.source: The query retrieves the building ID and the difference between the target and actual temperatures for each building on a given date.
trans-unit.target: The query retrieves the building ID and the difference between the target and actual temperatures for each building on a given date.

trans-unit.source: Press SHIFT + ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Press SHIFT + ENTER.

trans-unit.source: The %sql statement at the beginning tells the notebook to use the Spark SQL interpreter.
trans-unit.target: The %sql statement at the beginning tells the notebook to use the Spark SQL interpreter.

trans-unit.source: You can look at the defined interpreters from the Interpreter tab in the notebook header.
trans-unit.target: You can look at the defined interpreters from the Interpreter tab in the notebook header.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows the output.
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows the output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Run a Spark SQL statement using the notebook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Run a Spark SQL statement using the notebook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the display options (highlighted in rectangle) to switch between different representations for the same output.
trans-unit.target: Click the display options (highlighted in rectangle) to switch between different representations for the same output.

trans-unit.source: Click Settings to choose what consitutes the key and values in the output.
trans-unit.target: Click Settings to choose what consitutes the key and values in the output.

trans-unit.source: The screen capture above uses buildingID as the key and the average of temp_diff as the value.
trans-unit.target: The screen capture above uses buildingID as the key and the average of temp_diff as the value.

trans-unit.source: You can also run Spark SQL statements using variables in the query.
trans-unit.target: You can also run Spark SQL statements using variables in the query.

trans-unit.source: The next snippet shows how to define a variable, Temp, in the query with the possible values you want to query with.
trans-unit.target: The next snippet shows how to define a variable, Temp, in the query with the possible values you want to query with.

trans-unit.source: When you first run the query, a drop-down is automatically populated with the values you specified for the variable.
trans-unit.target: When you first run the query, a drop-down is automatically populated with the values you specified for the variable.

trans-unit.source: Paste this snippet in a new paragraph and press SHIFT + ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Paste this snippet in a new paragraph and press SHIFT + ENTER.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows the output.
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows the output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Run a Spark SQL statement using the notebook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Run a Spark SQL statement using the notebook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For subsequent queries, you can select a new value from the drop-down and run the query again.
trans-unit.target: For subsequent queries, you can select a new value from the drop-down and run the query again.

trans-unit.source: Click Settings to choose what consitutes the key and values in the output.
trans-unit.target: Click Settings to choose what consitutes the key and values in the output.

trans-unit.source: The screen capture above uses buildingID as the key, the average of temp_diff as the value, and targettemp as the group.
trans-unit.target: The screen capture above uses buildingID as the key, the average of temp_diff as the value, and targettemp as the group.

trans-unit.source: Restart the Spark SQL interpreter to exit the application.
trans-unit.target: Restart the Spark SQL interpreter to exit the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Interpreter tab at the top, and for the Spark interpreter, click Restart.
trans-unit.target: Click the Interpreter tab at the top, and for the Spark interpreter, click Restart.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Restart the Zeppelin intepreter</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Restart the Zeppelin intepreter</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this section, you use a Jupyter notebook to run Spark SQL queries against a Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you use a Jupyter notebook to run Spark SQL queries against a Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: The notebook you create following the instructions below is also available by default on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The notebook you create following the instructions below is also available by default on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After you have launched Jupyter, you will find this notebook by the name HVACTutorial.ipynb.
trans-unit.target: After you have launched Jupyter, you will find this notebook by the name HVACTutorial.ipynb.

trans-unit.source: Launch the Jupyter notebook.
trans-unit.target: Launch the Jupyter notebook.

trans-unit.source: From the Spark cluster blade, click Quick Links, and then from the Cluster Dashboard blade, click Jupyter Notebook.
trans-unit.target: From the Spark cluster blade, click Quick Links, and then from the Cluster Dashboard blade, click Jupyter Notebook.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: Create a new notebook.
trans-unit.target: Create a new notebook.

trans-unit.source: Click New, and then click Python2.
trans-unit.target: Click New, and then click Python2.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Jupyter notebook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Jupyter notebook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A new notebook is created and opened with the name Untitled.pynb.
trans-unit.target: A new notebook is created and opened with the name Untitled.pynb.

trans-unit.source: Click the notebook name at the top, and enter a friendly name.
trans-unit.target: Click the notebook name at the top, and enter a friendly name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provide a name for the notebook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provide a name for the notebook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Import the required modules and create the Spark and SQL contexts.
trans-unit.target: Import the required modules and create the Spark and SQL contexts.

trans-unit.source: Paste the following snippet in an empty cell, and then press SHIFT + ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Paste the following snippet in an empty cell, and then press SHIFT + ENTER.

trans-unit.source: Everytime you run a job in Jupyter, your web browser window title will show a (Busy) status along with the notebook title.
trans-unit.target: Everytime you run a job in Jupyter, your web browser window title will show a (Busy) status along with the notebook title.

trans-unit.source: You will also see a solid circle next to the Python 2 text in the top-right corner.
trans-unit.target: You will also see a solid circle next to the Python 2 text in the top-right corner.

trans-unit.source: After the job completes, this will change to a hollow circle.
trans-unit.target: After the job completes, this will change to a hollow circle.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Status of a Jupyter notebook job</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Status of a Jupyter notebook job</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Load sample data into a temporary table.
trans-unit.target: Load sample data into a temporary table.

trans-unit.source: When you provision a Spark cluster in HDInsight, the sample data file, hvac.csv, is copied to the associated storage account under \HdiSamples\SensorSampleData\hvac.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a Spark cluster in HDInsight, the sample data file, hvac.csv, is copied to the associated storage account under \HdiSamples\SensorSampleData\hvac.

trans-unit.source: In an empty cell, paste the following snippet and press SHIFT + ENTER.
trans-unit.target: In an empty cell, paste the following snippet and press SHIFT + ENTER.

trans-unit.source: This snippet registers the data into a temporary table called hvac.
trans-unit.target: This snippet registers the data into a temporary table called hvac.

trans-unit.source: Once the job completes successfully, the following output is displayed.
trans-unit.target: Once the job completes successfully, the following output is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Restart the kernel to exit the application.
trans-unit.target: Restart the kernel to exit the application.

trans-unit.source: From the top menu bar, click Kernel, click Restart, and then click Restart again at the prompt.
trans-unit.target: From the top menu bar, click Kernel, click Restart, and then click Restart again at the prompt.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Restart the Jupyter Kernel</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Restart the Jupyter Kernel</linkText>
